metadata.title: Excess Heat Production in Electrolysis of Potassium Carbonate Solution with Nickel Electrodes

affiliation: Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University Kita-ll, Nishi-10, Kita-ku, Sapporo O6O

body_text.text: With the aim of realizing the potassiun-proton cold fusion, the electrolysis of light water solution of potassium carbonate was carried out by neans of porous nickel cathode. The cell was cooled by a con stant rate air stream and maintained at 20PC during all the electrolysis. Typical results indicated that the excess heat production rate was proportional to the input power in the range $\\\\\\\\\\\circ\\\\\\\\\\\mathbf{f}$ measurements(up to 2W) and the excess heat observed was 3 to 4 times greater than the input power, after corrected for the thermo-neutral potential.

After the electrolysis, the calcium ion concentration in the electrolytes was measured by flame photospeetronetry and the increases of calciun concentration in the electrolytes due to the electrolysis were found to be $3. 2$ to 4.4 ppm. These amounts are comparable to the amounts of the excess heat calcura $\\\\\\\\\\\vdash$ ed within the same order of magunitued.

It was a shocking news that nuclear reactions of deuterium occurred on paradium cathode at. room temper-aturel The study of "cold fusion" has burst into flame throughout the world. Moreover, the novel type of the cold fusion in light water was suggested by still are doubtful about them, because of little reproducibility and consistence among the amounts of

their products, heat emission and radiation. However. these systems are essentially the most popular ones ERowhydnRDisvolukis"LisactioeralNactnde'seEaluP bpd that several aetive netals for hydrogen evolution reaction, for example, nickel. formed considerable amounts $. \\\\\\\\\\\mathrm{o f}$ the alkali metallic intermediates  during electrolysis of alkaline solutions. On the basis o $\\\\\\\\\\\mathbf{f}$ them, the nuclear reaction of potassium was sufficiently likely and therefore warranting further investigation. The aim of this work was to obtain the unequivocal evidence of this nuclear reaction.

An electrolytic cell made of Pyrex glass was used for the experiment and equipped with 3 electrodes, these being, a l x 0.5 x O.l cm sintered nickel test-electrode, platinum counter and platinum reference electrodes. A 20 milli-liter light water's solution of potassium carbonate with a concentration of O.5 mol per liter was used as the electrolyte, and stirred by bubbling hydrogen gas, with gas stream rate of l.5 m1 $. min during the electrolysis. The nickel electrode was cathodically polarized by a stationary constant current from 0.0l to 0.70 ampere and the temperature of the electrolyte was measured. A standard nichrome heating wire with a resistance of l5 ohm was put in the cell for comparison. The electrolysis was carried out using the twin celles simultaneously, in order to confirm that the heat discharged was only by electrolysis. The twin cells were placed a thermostat chamber of the temperature held at 20.00 t0.01*C during the electrolysis by air convection.
